review_title: Good professional development; poor employee pay & benefits
job_title: Campus Staff Minister in Madison, WI
pros: There's a good amount of opportunity for professional development and growth into different roles. Whatever you had interest in, there were generally opportunities to talk to someone or seminars being held, because the organization is so flat. They have their own sister publishing company, so there are a lot of resources for continuing to learn personally and professionally. They aren't perfect, but I would give their ethnic diversity and inclusion high marks for an evangelical organization.
cons: The fundraising models they employed made it difficult to get by, especially in California. Your salary is an ongoing conversation with your supervisor, determined by what donations come in to support the ministry budget, which can chronically remain around minimum wage if you're focusing your efforts toward the campus. The health care provided was not great, and would come out of the ministry budget, sometimes (like in my case) impacting your pay.

review_title: Meaningful Experience, but will take its toll on you.
job_title: Campus Team Leader in Sacramento, CA
pros: You feel like the work is worthwhile and you get tones of project management, team leading and coaching experience. You can also invest a good portion of your time and energy into work that will grow you personally and professionally. Interpersonal communication, cross-cultural competency, and teaching skills are probably some of the most important skills you will need or develop on the job. This job can be great for networking with churches, non-profits, universities, and the local community. They create a great working environment for mothers and staff with families. One of the best maternity leave plans I've seen. Coworkers are there because they love the work, and everyone for the most part works really hard at their job. You'll receive lots of top notch training and you'll get to see some direct impacts of your work on students, faculty and peers. But you will always have more work than you have time to accomplish.
cons: You have to fundraise your ministry budget and income. And the only way to get benefits or a raise is to fundraise more and get it approved by a supervisor. The benefits are solid when it comes to mental health but aren't so great for other areas. The work easily bleeds into your life and it can be very difficult to maintain healthy boundaries with students, donors and supervisors. Your income will always be very very modest. They try to compensate for cost-of-living depending on where you live, but most staff live on a tight budget.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Chicago, IL
pros: InterVarsity has been my extended family for over 20 years. If you're a gifted woman in ministry, it is one of the best places to work in the US! There are many flexible roles as you go through various life stages (having children,  etc.) InterVarsity invests in the development of leaders, including its staff.  I never intended to be in the States this long, but I'm wrapping up 25 years. It has been a great place to be.
cons:
For managers, there can be a lot of travel and nights away from home. But, that is the nature of student ministry and management.  It really isn't more time than what you'd find in any fortune 500 company, or roles where people are on call.

And at this juncture, the organization is going through major restructuring, so many of the leaders (men and women) I looked up to have or are about to retire. That's not a bad thing, flesh blood is always good, but being a senior leader, it is a bit of a jolt to be older than the CEO and the majority of the EVPs and VPs. I'm sure once the dust settles, the tension from all the change will subside.

pros: Working primarily for one executive director who is a fantastic supervisor. He has great patience with me when I am in a learning curve. He responds to my questions and concerns immediately or as soon as he can. My job is flexible in hours allowing me to do other jobs in my own city. He doesn't micro-manage. He communicates clearly and in a courteous and fun way. The other staff and administrators I've worked with are all helpful, patient with me, and very friendly. The national staff conference (every 3 years) for me is not required. I have gone and felt very valued and affirmed. Learned a lot in some personal areas not related to administrative skills. This past conference though had no sessions geared for administrators. The conference prior did have. The organization as a whole, based on the people I have met (campus ministers and other staff) have been intellectually sharp, resourceful, sensitive to race, gender, ethnicity, language, social issues, etc. I have great respect for the executive team and the board. Very capable and with the appropriate wisdom and heart for a faith-based non-profit.

review_title: Gorgeous workplace, ministry has great potential, poor workplace culture
pros: Great vision and mission and a fantastic location. There's a lot of potential for this ministry because of its unique setting, its facilities and its rich history. The Guest Services Director is a delight with his servant heart, and I wish he oversaw more of the daily operations of actually serving guests.
cons:
Management is not held accountable, to the mission and vision of the camp or those of InterVarsity. There is very little transparency in the "why" behind a lot of what goes on at camp, and the longer I was there, the more I learned this is because most things are done "because that's just how we do them."
Good business practices, industry best practices and even some legal standards are generally not considered important factors in planning or decision-making. The Assistant Director has been the primary cause of the high staff turnover rate, and is the primary contributor to the unhealthy culture. He doesn't lead, he manipulates, using fear and dread that pushes the bounds of harassment.

review_title: Mission focused organization is well led with a clear strategic plan
pros: This organization has the highest ethical standards and remains clearly focused on its mission.  The organization promotes a high level of collegiality while maintaining clear line for reporting and responsibility.
cons: The organization has a tendency to segment itself at times so that clusters of job roles remain  in touch with one another but may not have as much communication and contact with other clusters as would benefit the organization.  There are few career pathways in place so advancement within the organization is not built into its operations.

pros: InterVarsity's healthcare benefits are strong and there's a pretty pro-family atmosphere. I've never felt disapproval for having to take sick time to take care of a kid. And the hours are pretty flexible, which is nice. Plus, it's a company doing good in the world.
cons: Systems, processes, workflow, clarity about decision-making--all the stuff needed to get work done well--are NOT InterVarsity's strong suites. Plus, it can be difficult to advance unless you have advanced degrees. But the pay is low, not commensurate with skills/experience.

pros: Being on staff with InterVarsity means having the best co-workers ever—people who love what they do, have an incredible work ethic, and are extremely capable. Spiritual investment and care is a priority for employees, and a level of professionalism is maintained while being a very people-centered organization. There’s a great deal of trust and freedom given to individuals, allowing staff to take initiative and try things, as well as to develop new skills.
cons: Depending on where you are and who you have, management can vary. High degrees of trust and individualization means any employee’s experience is dependent on where they are hired and who is in charge in that location.

pros: An organization that truly lives by its values. InterVarsity seeks to glorify God through the lives of college students. A great place for someone who is young, passionate, and cares about students. Strong intellectual foundation.
